figure.figDesc: Electrochemical control of conductivity in an organic memristor: A time-resolved X-ray fluorescence sttudy of ionic drift as a function of applied voltage Tatiana Berzina, Svetlana Erokhina, Paolo Camorani, Oleg Konovalov, Victor Erokhin, and M.P. Fontana Grazing incidence X-ray fluorescence measurements were applied for a time-resolved study of an organic memristor conductivity variation mechanism. Comparison of these results with electrical measurements has allowed to conclude that the variation of the fluorescence intensity of Rb ions is directly connected to the ionic charge transferred between the conducting polymer and solid electrolyte, which made up the device. In addition, the conductivity of the memristor was shown to be the function of the transferred ionic charge. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces, 1, 2115-2118 (2009).
